DIV1.P: As it is ACTED at the THEATRE in Lincolns-Inn-Fields, BY Her MAJESTY's sworn Servants.

Q.L: Sed quid opus teneras Mordaci radere vero
Auriculas? Videsis, ne majorum tibi fortè
Limina frigescant; sonat hic de nare canina

DIV1.P: LONDON, Printed for Jacob Tonson, within Grays-Inn Gate next Grays-Inn Lane. 1705.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE,
DIV1.L: YOU, who in furious Factions take Delight,
Know, you are not to be regal'd to Night;
These Scenes do no one sparring Blow afford,
But Peace and Moderation is the Word:
No side, nor Man on either side, is hit,
We single out no Courtier, Clown, or Cit,
And if you're angry, 'tis all wrong, you're bit.
Nor let the well-bred Man, of Parts and Taste,
Look sharp for Dainties at a Country Feast;
Expect no sprightly Turns, nor Language here,
But rest contented with your homely Chear,
'Tis such as we cou'd get at Croydon Fair.
Our Men of Mirth have never been at Court,
Where Beaux, and Belles, and gentler Wits resort,
Biters indeed! and of the better sort.
To bare bambouz'ling we may chance pretend,
Or by the Christen Name to catch a Friend;
But to some happier Wit we leave to tell,
Of those who in true Biting most excel.
For that great Work old Bards shall rise again,
And the Sicilian Maids renew the lofty Strain.
Let not a Rival Writer stir up Spight
In you, who judge of Comedy, or Write;
For tho' fond Parents on their Off-spring doat,
And ev'ry Ideot Author loves the Brat he got;
Yet ours gives freely up his Petit Piece,
And swears that you may use it as you please:
Nay, shou'd you take his Drolling in good part,
He owns this only as a youthful Start,
And sets no Claim up to the Comick Art.
So when keen Patriots pursue the Chace,
The shifting Statesman yields, and sues for Grace,
And to preserve his Carcase quits his Place.

LG.L: OF all the Taxes which the Poet pays,
Those Funds of Verse, none are so hard to raise
As Prologues and as Epilogues to Plays.
So many mighty Wits are gone before,
Th' have rifled all the Muses sacred Store;
Like Conqu'ring Armies thro' the Province pass'd,
Swept all, and left it ruin'd, void and waste.
Yet, Conscientious you can still demand
Large Contributions from the wretched Land;
Expect that we should still pursue the Theam,
Tho' you deny to us, what you allow'd to them.
Bold Satyr then you did permit to reign,
Satyr, that Noise and Nonsense cou'd restrain;
Then to be pleas'd and taught the Harers came,
They got Instruction, and the Poet Fame.
Then Strephon's Verse to either Sex gave Law,
And Charm'd the Fair, and kept the Fools in Awe.
But now, for Reasons to your selves best known,
Your Fathers Wit and Pleasures you disown;
Hither ye Herds of Fools securely come;
Prologue and Epilogue,
Your antient Foes, are muzzled now and dumb.
We Women think it hard, when Laws prevail
That take away our Privilege to rail;
Maids, Wives and Mistresses, assert the Cause,
In spight of Reformaion and the Laws:
And tho' the censur'd Stage no Tales must tell,
Yet Visiting-Days and Tea may do as well.
Henceforth, in solemn Meetings of the Fair,
Our own dear Sex and all their Failings spare;
Let no ill-natur'd She severely say
What hideous ill-dress'd Things she saw that Day:
Let envious Ugliness no more reprove
Her fairer Friend's successful Pow'r in Love;
But let each able Tongue do all she can,
Let Satyr be the Word, and the whole Subject Man.
Tell of dull Knights, sad Squires, and wretched Cits,
Displaying Poets, and brisk biting Wits;
Then say, what Wine, what Friends, what choice Delights,
Employ their dull Days, and yet duller Nights;
Lash ev'ry Fool, of ev'ry Kind and Fashion,
And be the true Reformers of the Nation.

LIST.LABEL: Sir Timothy Tallapoy, An East-India Merchant, very Rich, in Love with Mariana, a great Affecter of the Chinese Customs.
Pinch, A biting Squire.
Clerimont, Nephew to Sir Timothy.
Friendly, In Love with Angelica.
Scribblescrabble, A City Sollicitor.
Bandileer, A Foot Soldier.
Trick, Servant to Friendly.
Grumble, Servant to Pinch.
Bohee, Servant to Sir Timothy.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.LABEL: Lady Stale, An affected amorous old Widow.
Mariana, Privately marry'd to Cleri∣mont, and related to Friendly.
Angelica, Daughter to Sir Timothy.
Mrs. Clever.
Mrs. Scribblescrabble,

LIST.ITEM: Servants belonging to Sir Timothy, Two Whores.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.

SP.P: FRiendly stays somewhat long, for so passionate a Person as he seems to be. This Laziness in Love looks as if Matrimony had gone before, and the best part of the Bus'ness bad been over.—Oh Trick!
Where's your Master?
He'll be here in a minute, Sir; just get rid of a little Misfortune that follows him.
Misfortune! What Misfortune?
My Lady Stale.
The Devil! Is she with him?

Too true, Sir:—Your ancient Gentlewoman is a tenacious Animal,—they seldom loose their hold 'till they have drawn Blood;—tho' to give my Master his due, he lives after a frank manner enough with her;—he'll make
no scruple of dropping her, leave her to daggle about the Fair by her self, at the first Stop she makes; we shall have him here presently.—See, didn't I tell you so, Sir.
Dear Cletimont, I have Ten Thousand Pardons to beg of you; I trespass upon your Patience at a strange rate.
Dear Sir, truce with your Compliments; and, if you please, let us come to the Matter in hand — Yon new House is my Uncle's.
'Two'd ha' made your Honour a pretty Seat, if you had not falln out with him.

He has been there with his Daughter these Three Days, —you are in love with her, have a mind to marry her; — he's a fantastical obstinate old Fellow, and resolves against parting either with her or his Mony, but to a Cox∣comb of his own chusing; who (by the way) came down in the same Coach with me to day,—so that unless we can find out some Stratagem to make an Ass of him, and a happy Man of you, poor Angelica must die a Maid, or marry the Fool, as aforesaid.
In order to that we have already taken all measures, tho' I must own I apprehend some Difficulty in the Execu∣tion of 'em —Did the Booby Lover that came with you know you?
Not at all. —I'll assure you he's a most extraordi∣nary Person, and a Biter, as his miserable Fellow-Travel∣lers, the very Coachman, and indeed every body we met upon the Road found to their Cost.

The Devil he is! That new Generation of Wags are the most insufferable Teizers!—It happens luckily e∣nough; for your Uncle has met with 'em some where or o∣ther, and I suppose has been bit to the purpose, for he raves at the very mention of the Word, swears 'tis a villai∣nous Design to corrupt all our Morality, and breed up our Youth in the Practice of early Lying; he hopes to see it made Felony by Act of Parliament.—I perceive my
Rival will hardly prove so formidable as we took him to be.

Fear nothing, Sir; Rug's the Word, all's safe. For the old Gentleman, leave him to me. This Fair-time gives his Country Neighbours a Liberty of coming to his House, tho' the Inside of it at another time is as hard to be seen as a fortify'd Place in the time of War,—but the Devil's in him if he can keep us out now:—I have engag'd two or three very pretty Fellows here of the Town to be of the Party with us, smart Dogs for the contriving part, and of most invincible passive Courage to go thro' with the Execution,—they have had the Honour to be beaten black and blue in several Adventures already.

For the rest, the lovely Mariana, your charming Kinswoman, has engag'd a notable Limb of the Law, a Ci∣ty Sollicitor, in your Interests;—if there be any thing in his way of Roguery to do you Service you may depend upon him. My Uncle is luckily enough too in Love with Mariana, to a very ridiculous Extravagance; and when a Woman of Wit and Beauty has an old Fellow under those Circumstances, she seldom fails of a Secret to make him pliant.
But can you, who are so delicate a Lover, allow Mariana to make any Advances to this extravagant Uncle of yours?
To trust you then with a Secret of the last Impor∣tance, you must know I have been marry'd to her this Week.—
To Mariana!
She has made me the happiest Man in the World.
Does your Uncle know any thing of this Matter?
Not a Syllable; I have been so long upon survy Terms with him, that I thought 'twou'd be to little pur∣pose to ask his Consent.

Sir, Sir, as I live yonder's Mrs. Clever;—Mr. Cle∣rimont is in Disgrace with his Uncle, and I being in some∣what scoundrelish, or, as your Honour calls it, [To Cler.]
scurvy Terms with him my self, what if we shou'd retain her for an opening Council towards him?
Ha! lucky enough.
S'death! She's an intimate Friend of my Lady Stale's.

Ah dear Sir, she hath a violent Passion for Mony;— she loves it better, not than any thing, I wo'nt say that of her neither, but than any Friend that ever she had, from her God-fathers and God-mothers to the last new Acquain∣tance she made.
Prithee call her—I have been mightily in her Books of late.
Hum! not altogether so proper just now;— my Lady Stale has join'd her, and they are both coming this way.

Let's be gone;—I wou'd not see her.—And d'ye hear, Sirrah, contrive some way to rid us of my Lady Stale;—that unlucky amorous Five and Forty Face of hers is a meer Omen of ill Fortune,— I wish we may ne∣ver meet her 'till our Projects are past crossing.
I warrant you, Sir: And for Mrs. Clever you may reckon the thing done;— you may depend upon her as much as the French King does upon his Cousin of Bava∣ria. Exeunt.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Stale, and Mrs. Clever.

SP.P: Well, dear Clever, never talk, for this Croydon is a most insufferable filthy Place.

There's a great deal of Hurry, Dust and Noise in∣deed. And yet so there are at May Fair and Bartholemew Fair, where all the World come.—Methinks this Place is as diverting as those are, and the People are as merry here as there, tho' they are not so well dress'd.

Dress'd! the Creatures! why, Child, Dressing's a reasonable thing—one must have a fine Wit, delicate and well turn'd, to be able to Dress.— The things that come here never think, they love Walnuts and Sack, and fat
Goose, and seeing of Monsters, and laughing á Gorge de∣ployeé, but they never think.—Well I am perfectly glad I have met thee.—I'll swear I believe I am the only Wo∣man of Condition here.—I'll swear I'm in the last Con∣fusion to think I could have so much Complaisance for Friendly to come hither.—I'll swear I believe you must think me furiously fond, to let him engage me in a Party so horribly upon the ridiculous.

We have dropt him some where in the Crowd, and I fancy 'tis that makes you so uneasie.—Come, Madam, confess, is it not Jealousie, rather than Complaisance, en∣gages you in all Friendly's Parties? To give the Man his due, methought he was not so very pressing for your Com∣pany hither.

Jealous! poor Clever! I jealous of the Fellow! I swear, Madam, you're as much mistaken, Madam, as perhaps you ever were in your Life, Madam. After all, when one is made so very much to one's Advantage, so a∣greeable, so handsom, so every thing in the World, and when one has so fine a Discernment to understand it very well one's self, Jealousie is a Passion that perhaps after all is as little troublesome as any Passion in the World.
Oh, Madam! all the World must confess how bountiful Nature has been to you, even to the last Prodi∣gality of Gifts and Graces.

Why really, and between Friends, Child, I don't think my Person has done Nature one jot of Discredit— What do you think? ha! as long as good Faces have been in Fashion, she never finish'd one more to her Reputation.
Ay, ay, Madam, take your Person all together you have all the reason in the World to be satisfy'd with it.

Nay, my Dear, that I am, upon my Word;—for, as I was saying, I think I may, without Affectation, aver that I am handsom, rich, nay and young too, in spight of all the little insignificant World may say to the contrary.

Why that's true—that same World is the De∣vil— the ridiculous ways they have got in that World!— You shall have 'em, when they are vex'd at their Hearts that
they grow old themselves, fancy that every Body else grows old in proportion as they do: You shall have 'em, because they happen'd to Dance at a Ball with a Woman, in the merry Days of King Charles the Second, cry, smoak the reverend Gentlewoman, tho' she has as much Cherry-colour'd Ribbon, and black Hair fruz'd out as any Toast of 'em all, and never miss'd the Front-Box of a new Play these Thirty Years.
The World is full of Impertinences— but you may take my Word for it, that I am young, very young.
Oh dear Madam! you don't think there is any oc∣casion to convince me of it.
No, Child, not at all as to that;—but besides now, besides all these Accomplishments, I ought to pique my self somewhat upon my Birth and Family.
Why that is very hard now, as to this damn'd World again.
As how, dear Clever?

As how? why that there should be such a thing as Scandal — that Virtue and Merit, like your Ladyships, should run the Gantlet thro' so many Visiting Days every Week.—Why I believe I have heard a Thousand Peo∣ple say, that you never had Father or Mother, Uncle or Aunt, Sister or Brother, that your self or any other Body knew of—nay, not so much as a Husband, tho' your Ladyship has had the Misfortune to be a disconsolate Wi∣dow for so many Years last past.

This is pleasant I vow! but, dear Clever, this is particularly pleasant—the ridiculous World! as if eve∣ry Body did not know my Family.—I'd have 'em to comprehend I have Two as fine young Gentlemen as ever wore Gowns at the University —the worst of 'em, (and indeed I think that is Jeremy) the worst of'em understands Hebrew — And then my Neice at Hackney is the pretti∣est witty Creature.

Ah, Madam, 'tis not your Fertility is in Question, no Body can have the Impudence to dispute that part of
your Family—Your Posterity is all safe, but 'tis con∣cerning your Illustrious Ancestors that the Doubt is rais'd.
Folly to the last degree!—I swear you begin to be mighty entertaining.
You'll pardon me, Madam, that I have dealt so very freely with your Ladyship—You'll allow for the Sincerity of Friendship.
Oh by all means, my Dear, you wrong me to suspect the contrary—I have Wit enough to be above the little Envy of those talking things—besides I am Rich, have a Fortune, Argent Comptant, Child.
A Fortune!
Ay, Clever, a Fortune.
Nay, then I don't wonder at your being above what the World can say of you.—Positively no Body can be out of Humour that has Mony enough.
I think I have some kind of an Inclination to Mr. Friendly—the Man loves me to Folly;—I am pleas'd he should do so, and, in short, I intend he shall marry me within these Two Days.

Well, Madam, I wish you good Success—but the World, that has been so ill-natur'd to dispute one Hus∣band with you, may try to hinder you of another — therefore have a Care, and make sure of your Man while you can have him. — Between the Wars abroad, and the many pressing Occasions at home, Men are scarce.
My Lady Stale! Is it possible that I should meet you here?
Mariana! this is the very Predestination of good Fortune— my Dear, Dear, incomparable Dear!— But, Child! what, are you alone?

Oh no, Madam,—the Diversions of this Place draw so much Company to 'em, that 'twould be almost impossible to come alone, especially in a Stage-Coach.—
To deal freely with you, I came hither upon an Engage∣ment with Mr. Clerimont.
And the rest of your Company?
Gallant and engaging to the last degree. A Tem∣pler, a Lady of Wit and Pleasure, and a notable Man of Business out of the City.
I suppose your Ladyship can give a very good Ac∣count of the Inns of Court Gallantry?
Oh, Mrs. Clever, your Servant. — You have brought your usual good Humour hither, I see.
I am always very much at your Service, Madam.
Well, but how have you dispos'd of your Com∣pany?
All dispers'd — my young Squire was taken up with Four or Five fine Ladies in Masks.
And your Lady of Pleasure?
With a Knot of Rakes. — And my Man of Bu∣siness is engag'd in an Affair of Consequence.
An Affair of Consequence at Croydon.
Ay, I'll assure you, and very great too.— A Whim took him to give himself a t'other End o'the Town kind of an Air, and he wou'd not pay the Coach-Man— whereupon—
I suppose he beat him.
Even so, from Top to Toe— He had just fi∣nish'd him when I left 'em.
Very pleasant!—But, my Dear, have you met with no Adventure your self?
Oh with a very good one, I assure you:— A Granadier of the Guards proffer'd to Treat me with burnt Brandy and Sawsages.
Very gallant!
Oh shocking! But 'tis like the horrible Place— I swear, my Dear, we ought never to be forgiven for com∣ing hither.

Oh dear Madam, be compos'd, I beseech you— my Life on't you meet with none of those Insolences.—
Such little wild young Creatures as Mariana can't avoid the Impertinence of an impudent young Fellow; but he must be a Granadier indeed that would attack your Ladyship.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr. Scribblescrabble, bloody and dirty.

SP.P: Ah dear Mr. Scribblescrabble! I rejoice to see you— I am glad you're got out of the Clutches of that unmerciful pounding Coachman.
Ah de-de-dear Madam, your Slave, your Slave, no∣thing in the Earth, a Te-Te-Trifle, a Trifle.
Is this the Lawyer, Child?
The same.
One always meets with your me-me-merry Wags, and your comical Jo-Jokes, Madam, at Fairs and such like Places;—for my part, I came a pu-pu-pu-purpose—
To be beaten? A very whimsical Design, very far from a Jest, and in my Opinion went off very tragically on your side.
Not at all, Madam, not at all, a Te-Te-Trifle, a Trifle.
Your Nose bleeds sadly.
Nothing at all, very good, very wholsome;—I always bleed Spring and Fall.
Men of Gallantry turn every thing into good Hu∣mour and Mirth.—I know Mr. Scribblescrabble of old al∣ways a Wag.
Ah! Na-Na-Nanny! Nanny Clever! By Je-Je-Jericho I'm glad to see thee.
He's a great Man at Adventures,—the Farthing Py-houses in Moor-fields ring of him.
Well, to have Adventures is always a Mark of a Man of Condition. Mr. Scribblescrabble, give me leave to felicitate your good Fortune.
Ah dear Madam, you don't know him.—He's intimate with all the agreeable Rakes bout Town, wears a lac'd Hat with a smart Pinch in Vacation-time, and plays at Picket at the Temple Chocolate-houses.
Tr-truly, Madam, if it were not discountenanc'd in the City, I do think a de-de-demy Castor, with a fashi∣onable Edging, a very Ge-Ge-Gentleman-like kind of an Ornament.
He is a very Terror to all the Husbands of the Ward he lives in, —Two Chandlers Wives, besides a Haberdasher of small Wares's Daughter, have been turn'd out of doors for him within this Half Year.
Ah me-me-meer Waggery, Sc-Sc-Scandal.— What shou'd the Ladies see in me?
Oh that Spirit, that Wit, that agreeable Freedom.
Something of a fr-fr-frank manner, Madam; ah, ha, ha,—but wh-what's that, what's that, Madam?— But how come you to know he! I value my self upon be∣ing close.
What, d'ye think the World knows nothing?— But besides, whatsoever he says, he loves to make a Noise with his Adventures.
Aa, fy, fy, fy,—no, no, no. Making an ugly Face.
Pretty Expression of his Passion!
Then 'tis the little peevishest Creature, rather than not quarrel he'll quarrel and box with his Mistress her self; then she, you know, naturally resists, then an Uproar, out come the Prentices—
What! engage with the Domesticks?
Up with Paring-shovels, Blows abound, and the Lover is ruefully beaten for the Close of his Adventure.
Suffering for the Ladies is gallant; and you see Love is his foible. But what says poor Madam Scribble∣scrabble to all this.
A a a.
His Wife? What has he a Wife! Oh unfaithful Mr. Scribblescrabble!
Na-na-name her not, name her her not, I say.
Marry but we will tho'—since, to her Praise be it spoken, she's an Example to the whole Parish for Patience and good Huswifry.
Shall I tell you? My Dru-Drudge, my Conveni∣ence, my patient Grissel,—she in the Be-Be-Ballad was a Type of her, and I am her n-n-noble Marquis, her Lord, her great Turk, by Je-Jericho.
What a barbarous little gallant Person it is!
Why didn't you bring her with you to day?
What, about bu-bu-bus'ness?—Inco-co-congru∣ous, Madam.—No, I left her, I left her—
Pensively at home, I warrant you.
Mending the foul Clothes, and the Childrens Stock∣ings;—but let us leave her to her Co-Co-Cowheel and Pint of Ale, and talk of other Matters.—Have you seen Mem-Mem-Mr.—? To Mariana.
aside. Husht! a Word with you.—No naming of Names—hark in your Ear.
You see, Madam, what a base World it is, how false the Men and how miserable the Women are:—The very Scribblescrabbles of the City have got into the way of despising their Wives.

'Tis too true, Child; and there are very few in this fantastical Age that the greatest Merit can oblige to Con∣stancy: — And if I didn't think Friendly a Man that had a very exact Goût for Merit, one that enter'd very far into Merit, extreamly far, almost as far as 'tis possible for one to enter into Merit, I should hardly trust my self in his or any Man's Hands.

Look ye, Madam, he may enter into Merit as far as another, I don't dispute that, Madam; but how will you keep him from being weary of Merit, and having his Belly full of Merit, as they say, getting rid of Merit, turn∣ing Merit off again?
For that, Child, I trust to my Merit, 'tis my own, I know it, and I trust to it.
Matrimony's an uncertain Game.

'Tis so. — But you know we Women love Play.— Besides, Railery apart, my Physicians tell me that I shall never be free from the Tooth-ach, Vapours, and a scurvy
Humour that haunts me Spring and Fall, 'till, ah! ah! (you'll pardon the Misfortune of my Constitution) 'till I have another Child.—Nay, they say if I had Twins 'twou'd be better, and go more to the bottom of my Di∣stemper.
Nay then you had best get your Ingredients toge∣ther, and go into the Course as soon as possible, for scar the Season for Physick should be over.
My dear, I see you're busie. [To Mariana.] We'll go on before.
But a Word, Madam, and I wait on you.
Clever and I'll walk on before—you'll overtake us before we get to the Monsters—I have a strange Fan∣cy for Monsters.
Did your Ladyship ever see the Mantegur?
Oh dear! no—he was a very obscene Mon∣ster—he was obscene, rude, very rude and beastly — but the Womantegur—
His Lady?
—Was very well bred, and had a great deal of Wit.—This is her Day, I believe, if she sees Company here; well visit her.
With all my heart. Exeunt.
Look ye, be careful, and you may expect every thing from Mr. Friendly's Bounty;—for Clerimont's Un∣kle, I'll undertake he shall set his Name to the Deeds when they are ready.
'Tis enough; they are here in pu-pu-presto in my Green-bag here; I want nothing but the old Ge-Ge-Gen∣tleman's Name to fill up the Blanks with.
For that I can inform you—he writes himself Sir Timothy Tallapoy of Kingquangungxi.
What a pu-pu-plaguy Pagan N-Name is that for a Protestant Pu-Pu-Parish!

'Tis a Name he has given to a new House he has built hard by here. You must know he got his Estate by the China Trade in the East-Indies, and at that time grew so fantastically fond of the Manners, Language, Habit, and
every thing that relates to those People, that he prefers 'em not only before those of his own Country, but all the World beside. 'Tis ridiculous enough to see how he makes him∣self be dress'd and serv'd exactly after the Chinese manner.
Ve-very whimsical, fe-fe-faith and troth.
But husht!—here's our Fellow-Traveller, the Temple Wag, that came down in the Coach with us.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Pinch, and Two Women in Masks.

SP.P: You tell me you are very passionate—

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Mask.
SP.P: What, are you such a Monster not to believe me when I swear?
It is really inconsistent.—You have known me but Two Minutes and a half, and you intend to bambouzle me out of a Beef Stake.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ma.
SP.P: Not for that, my Dear, indeed;—but if we shou'd dine together we should be so facetious—and I can tell you something of some body that lodges at the Black-boy and Still in a certain Place.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ma.
SP.P: Hark ye, Madam, come away, Madam,—We won't be beholding to the Pimp.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ma.
SP.P: No, pray stay. Madam; I'll assure you, Madam, I know the Gentleman,—he is a Relation of mine, and—
Bite!

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ma.
SP.P: What d'ye mean, Pimp? ha, Pimp! What's Bite, Pimp? Will you give us a Bottle of Wine or no, Pimp?
Why then I tell you no▪ —And now I have told you my Mind without a Bite, pox.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ma.
SP.P: Dammee, Madam, come away, Madam;— there's Madam Footstocking at the Greyhound—she has brought down a couple of Bob Wigs out of Cheapside shall treat us both.—Look ye, Pimp, I shall meet you some Night or other in the Play-house Passage, and then I'll bite you, I will so, Pimp you! Exeunt Masks.
Mr. Pinch, your Servant;—I vow I'm afraid you're very ill-natur'd —you treated your Ladies very roughly, methought.
Oh dear no, Madam, by no means, Madam — I am fond of the Fair to the last degree; by the solemn Powers I am, Madam.—Your Ladyship is, as I may say, a Biter, Madam.
Upon my Word 'tis very innocently, for I don't know what it is.
Oh dear, Madam, excuse me for that—no, no, bite, bite, Madam, that won't pass indeed.
Nay I must confess I take it to be something that is very entertaining, because I see it makes up a great part of the Conversation among you fine Gentlemen.
Oh your only new way of Humour.—We that pretend to be Men of Wit and Pleasure do nothing but Bite all Day long.
But pray, Sir, as how? for Example a little.
Why as thus; suppose now I should say Sir Simon Snuffle was a Wit.
A Wit! he's a Politician indeed, and a smart little Gentleman; but for a Wit—

Bite! there 'tis now—Why he's no more a Wit than I am a Politician. Or now if I should say I am going to Moscow, or that I am to be Lord Mayor, or that the Cham of Tartary's my Cousin-German, that the Pope's a Whig, and the French King a Reformer, Beauty to be a∣bolish'd, and Matrimony and ugly Faces to prevail, how say you with a grave Face indeed? Bite, says I—that's all;—you see 'tis the easiest thing in the World.
Me-me-mighty easie fe-fe-Faith and Troth.— Why this is nothing but lying—Here have I been a Bi∣ter, Man and Boy, these Thirty Years, and never knew it.
Well I see you are a true Biter, and a right Wit of the Age, by winding up your Jest with Matrimony— but have you been a Sufferer by the Ladies, that you speak ill of their Profession?

Pardon me, not at all, Madam, only for the Grace of Wit, and to make up the troll of the Sentence, as mer∣rily conceited Persons are us'd to do. I am Matrimony's humble Servant, came down to this very individual Town of Croydon to pay my Respects to it, and am to subscribe my self Matrimony's Bond-slave to morrow.
And who is the Nymph that is to be made happy?
Happy! ah ha, Bite, Madam.—I am to be mar∣ry'd indeed, but no Body's to be made happy.
You are such a Wag one dos'nt know where to have you.—Well, but who is it that is to have the Ho∣nour of being your bitten Bride,—for bit she will be, that I foresee already.
Right, Madam, for, as you say, I shall bite her, tho' she be Bone of my Bone never so much.—You must know 'tis one Madam Angelica, Daughter to Sir Timothy Tallapoy, a rich Merchant hard by here.
Handsome to a Miracle, I suppose.

'Egad I don't know, that's as the Fates shall ap∣point — for you must know I never saw her nor her Fa∣ther in my Life, nor hear of 'em 'till within these Three Days, when a Comical old Fellow, a Father of mine in the Country, sends me up a Servant of his, one Gregory Grumble by Name, (whom, by the way, I bit Seven times before he could tell how my Father and Mother, my Bro∣thers and Sisters, my Uncles and Aunts, and the rest of my Relations in the Country did) to tell me that he had agreed with a Gentleman for a Wife for me.—I receiv'd the News, bit the Bearer again, and then sent him to notifie to my Father-in-Law that is to be.
And in Consequence thereof you are come down hither?
To bite the Old Gentleman and the rest of my Croydonian Relations, consummate with his Daughter, and beget a biting Generation for the benefit of Posterity.
aside to Scr. You see this is your Man—besure you don't lose sight of him.
Te-te-tace's the Word, Madam,—a Word to the Wise—I'll be-be-bite him, I warrant you.
You're so intent upon this Fair Lady, that I'm a∣fraid we must despair of your good Company.

For that Fair Lady you speak of time enough— I'll marry her to morrow time enough, I'll warrant you— I'll marry her—Can she desire more?— But for you, Madam, I wou'd forsake the greatest Princess upon the Earth, tho' she were fair as the blushing Morn—or—
Oh dear! this is a very particular piece of Gallan∣try,—but you Men of Wit and Pleasure are so en∣gaging—
For really, Madam, since the first happy Minute I had the Honour to know you,
Which was about Two Hours ago, Aside.
I have really hd the greatest Inclination in the World to profess my self, Madam, your Ladyships most profound humble Servant.
Nay, I swear this is too much—I would not make your Lady jealous for the World.
Madam, shall I tell your Ladyship without a Bite, and by the solemn Powers, I am passionate and sincere.
I have a strange Inclination to take you at your Word.
Od! and so do—here am I that will make it out.

Give me your Hand—I'll have a good Opinion of my Beauty, and intrench upon your Bride's Preroga∣tive; for this Day I receive you for my Servant, and if you don't like me when that's over, as well as you do now, you shall repair to your Lady Mistress at Night, and be marry'd to morrow for your Punishment.
Od! I like this mightily—strangely—Faith —Od! there's a good deal of Conceit in it—It's like a Carnival before Lent,—or a—
Come, hang Similes—we'll join the rest of our Company, and be as merry as the Day's long.
Or like—or hold—stay—or like a Biting and a Beating, or like Laughing and Crying, or like fair Weather and soul or like riding in a Coach and going a-foot afterwards,—or like—
Phoo! phoo!—Come along I'll warrant you—
Or like—Od! I don't know — like somewhat that's very merry and very melancholy— But, as you say, hang Similes, and so come along.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: CLOE blush'd, and frown'd, and swore,
And push'd me rudely from her;
I call'd her perjur'd, faithless Whore
To talk to me of Honour.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: But when I rose, and wou'd be gone,
She cry'd, nay, whither go ye;
Young Damon saw, now we're alone,
Do what you will with Cloe.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Timothy Tallapoy, Two or Three Servants ri∣diculously habited haling in Grumble.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: LOOK ye, Sirrah, I will put you into the Hands of the Tutang, whih is, according to Interpretation, the Officer that delighteth in Justice, which is, according to English Expression, the Constable of Croydon;—I'll see whether the Laws of this Land, as corrupt as they are, will allow you in Enormities like these.

Yaust charge the Counstable wi' ma'—Yaust put me i'th' Stocks now! Maister's Worship, Sir Pe∣ter Pinch's Worship, and my Lady Pinch's Worship, and young Maister Pinch's Worship, the young Squair's Worship, they'st tak'et huge kaindly o' yur Worship to put their Man i'th' Stoucks for bracking the Boble there.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Profane Rascall! Sirrah! It was the Pagode, or Representation of the great Callasusu, who was Ne∣phew to the Great Fillimafo, who was descended from the Illustrious Fokensi, who was the first Inventer of eat∣ing Rice upon Platters.—Sirrah! if you had been at Nanquin, or the great City of Xamsi, you had suffer'd Death, Sirrah! Death, you Varlet!
How now? What's the Matter? What has this Fellow done that he is taken into Custody?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: The Pagode, the Pagode, he has broken the great Pagode.
Is that all!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Get you in, Hussy, incontinently I say:— You have not that Regard and Veneration for things which deserve Regard and Veneration, which any civil∣ly, modestly, or virtuously disposed Person may have, can have, must have, and ought to have, Hussy.

Yau'st mak such a Raut and a Hurly-burly, an' yau'st no stay 'till young Maister come—here—I'se pay for't—I'se pay for't aut of my awn Pocket,— here, bauy another. Offering Mony. Here's a Rant with a Rallazu an a Zu, with a pox.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Monster of a Fellow!—Take him away from my sight—Confine him in the lowest Part of the Edifice, ev'n in the Cellar — Away with him, I say.— Exeunt Servants with Grumble. His Master will be here to day, and I will demand Ju∣stice of him —I will demand Two Hundred and Se∣venty od Blows on his Belly, Three Hundred on his Breech, and Four Hundred and Twenty Nine on the Soles of his Feet.—Well, Mistress, have you di∣spos'd your self incontinently to marry the Mandarin Mr. Pinch to morrow, according to my Commands?
To morrow, Sir? to morrow's very soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: By the Majesty of Pekin, an' you mutter, Hussy, I'll have you marry'd to Night, and then you'll be out of your Pin by to Morrow.

Pain, Sir?—Upon my Word, Sir, 'tis not the matter of the Pain, Sir, nor the being out of the Pain, that I stand upon; but upon my Word, 'tis a ve∣ry hard thing to be forc'd to marry a Man one don't like.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P:
Most provokingly impertinent! — to dis∣like a Man before she sees him, only in opposition to my Paternal Authority.—No, Hussy, I know the true
Reason—'tis not that you dislike him, but because you like somebody else; —you have set your Heart upon some of those vain frothy young Mandarins of that imperial, but abominably vicious City of London, call'd Beaux.

SP.L: Upon my Word, Sir,—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Be silent, I say.—For ought I know you design to join your self to one of that execrable new Sect which they call the Biters, those Sons of the Serpent that inhabits in the House of Smoak.—By the Great Lama, I had as soon see you marry'd to the Giant Tansu, who inhabits in the prodigious Mountains of Tartary, and eats a Hundred and Fifty Virgins every Day in the Week, but Fridays and Saturdays, and then he lives upon old Women, as good Catholicks do upon Stock-fish, by way of Mortification.
Well, Sir, you may do what you please with me, but I am sure you shall never make me forget poor Mr. Friendly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Ah ha! Said I not so? Does it go there?
For his Estate, 'tis as good as your Mandarin Pinch's; and for his Personal Qualifications, I'm sure I know 'em too well not to vindicate 'em against any Man∣darin in Christendom.
I don't know why I shou'd not pluck up Aside. a Spirit, and tell this old Chinese Father of mine his own.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Why hearken to me, my Daughter, (I will reason with her) thou hast been bred up like a virtuous and a sober Maiden, and would'st thou take the part of a profane Wretch, who sold his Stock out of the Old East-India Company, and show'd his scurrilous Wit in making a Jest of the worshipful Traders? A scur∣vy, idle Varlet! A wicked Varlet!—

Well, Sir, if he took his Stock out of one Fund that he was weary of, he'll put it into another that he likes
better; and that's what all the young Fellows about Town do, that understand Bus'ness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: A wicked, wicked Wretch!—He might have put it into the New then, if he did not like the Old,—but to be of neither!—Talk no more of him—thou wilt put me into a Chafe, and it will be the worse for thee.—A naughty ill-principled young Man, to be of neither East-India Company!
Well—but dear, dear Father, will you make me marry this scurvy Fellow I never saw?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: This is immoderately vexatious!—In good truth I am resolved.
Are you?—Why then so am I, and let the Mandarin look to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: What a prodigious thing is the Education of an English Damsel!
aside. How fantastical is the Difference between an old Fellow's Judgment, and a young Wench's In∣clinations! — Od! I have a good Mind to speak out. To Sir Tim. I must marry him then, you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Positively.

SP.L: Well, I shall make—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: A good Wife, I hope, Gentlewoman.

No—but what's all one, such a scurvy, abo∣minable, whimsical, coxcomical, miserable, oddish, ex∣emplary kind of a Husband of him, that the most potent Cham of Tartary, that you us'd to tell us of so, shan't show his Fellow among all the merry Men in his Coun∣try—and so I'm resolv'd I'll tell him the first time I see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P:
Well!—Incontinently this is a most fla∣gitious Age—nothing but Disobedience, Impudence, Debauchery, Biting, and all kind of Wickedness— but no matter;—I will comfort my self after the manner of the sage Philosopher Tychung, who liv'd
Fifteen Thousand Seven Hundred and Fourteen Years, Two Months and Three Days ago, and let the World rub—I will send forthwith to my Correspondent at Canton for a new Pagode—I will marry my Daugh∣ter to the young Man I have provided for her— and after that I will incontinently espouse the most amiable Mariana, and engender a Male Off-spring, who shall drink nothing but the Divine Liquor Ta, and eat nothing but Oriental Rice, and be brought up after the Institutions of the most excellent Confucius.—And I will moreover in the mean time divert the melancholy Faculties of my Mind in beholding the Diversions of this numerical Croydon Fair—I will behold the most noble Exercise of Dancing on the Ropes—I have be∣held it with Delight in the flourishing Empire of Chi∣na, I will behold it here again.— But lo! here are of the Frequenters of this Place—they seem Lipous, or Men of Rank—I will salute them according to the manner of the most glorious and wise City of Pe∣king.

DIV3.STAGE: Sir Timothy salutes 'em after the Chinese manner.

SP.P: Come along, my little Scribblescrabble,—we shall find the Ladies somewhere hereabouts—Hey! Who have we here! What, are you the Man with the Wax-works?
By Je-Je-Jericho, Sir Timothy Tallapoy. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Young Gentleman, may the Garden of your Graces be ever flourishing—but I delight not in Wax-works.
What then, the Vigo Plate?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: I am ignorant of your Intentions.
Husht! Squire, Squire Pinch! Aside.
Oh ho! What, you're the Man that bought the right Italian Fairy that was born at Hampsted?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: I am a Mandarin of this Neighbourhood, and delight in a new Mansion.
A Wo-Word w'ye. Aside to Pin.
Oh Pox! that's just at the Town's End, with Bottl'd Ale and Collard Beef over the Door; the Sussex-House.

Are you me-me-mad! — Come away, I tell you — this is a poor unfortunate Gentleman that's craz'd —He was Mace-bearer ro the Lord Chancellor of Moscow, and was turn'd out of his Place for having more Wit than his Master—poor Man, happen'd not to be dull enough to be in with that Ministry, lost his Place, hurt his Head, poor Man!
Very strange, Faith! Od, I'll bite him— I never bit a Mad-man in my Life.
Poo, poo!—Come away.
By the solemn Powers I will — Old Gentle∣man, your Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Most flourishing Youth, I congratulate your Arrival at the Village of Croydon—Came you from the Imperial City of Londom?
Yes, yes, we came from London.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: And do the most ingenious Imparters of No∣velty afford any thing that is new?
There's Comical News, Faith, in the Flying-Post—It's given out and rumour'd, that several Great Men, and Beglerbegs in the West-Indies, have declar'd for the Rebels in Hungary.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P:
Sir, shall I tell you? I am not concern'd for any Transactions which are or may be in the West-In∣dies.—Sir, you are a Stranger to me, but I deal plain∣ly with you, I am no Friend to any thing in the West, and am positively resolv'd, Sir, never to have any thing to do with Westminster, Westchester, West-Smithfield, or the West-Indies. No, Sir, the East, I think, is more
properly the Concern of every good and honest Man.— You take my meaning, Sir, and if you have any thing from the East-Indies so, Sir, for to tell you my Mind freely, I don't think there is a good Moral Man on this side the Cape of Good-hope.
By Je-Je-Jericho that's much!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Always excepting some of the worshipful Tra∣ders to the aforesaid East-Indies.
Why, Sir, both the Companies are concern'd in the Project, and are to furnish—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Sir, let me tell you, they are a wise and a prudent—
Bite! bite! my Dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: How, Sir! why? where? what? meaning whom? Staring.
What? why Bite, Old Gentleman, that's all, Bite!
Good lack! how he looks! de-de-dear Squire, come away.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: 'Tis all false! 'tis impossible! 'tis not in Na∣ture! Sir, you're a Son of a Bitch.—Sir, I am a Man∣darin of the Tribunal of Justice—I am a Trader to the most excellent Oriental Countries—I never was bit in my Life, nor ever will be bit, that's more, by the Majesty of Peking.
Dear Squire, have a Care, that's a very hard Stick in his Hand.
Let me alone, you shall see I'll fun him—I'll fun him, I warrant you.—Come old Gentleman, [To Sir Timothy.] no Harm, only a little Merriment— I give a Bite and I take a Bite—bite me again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: I wou'd as soon commit Felony or Treason— I thank a good Conscience, and a virtuous Education, I am none of those: Go, Sir, whoever you are, you're an idle young Man—and your Parents—But I say no more! I would not have any Child of mine come near you—for oh Dear! — Lifting up his Hands.
This is foolish enough, faith! this old Fellow is very hellish and very stupid—What an' I warrant you you take us Biters to be sad Dogs?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: By the Majesty of Peking and so I do—I take you to be worse than Popery, Slavery, Presbi∣tery, Rebellion, Plague, Fire, Famine, and a standing Army to boot.—What a Condition is this poor Nation in! What with Plotters in one Place, and Bi∣ters in another, and yet no Body's hang'd for ei∣ther.
What strange Enemies these old Fools are to us Wits!—Well! 'tis a wonderful thing in Nature, but certainly there is such a thing as Sympathy and Anti∣pathy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: I have, I thank my Stars, seen Governments where Immoralities of this kind were Death, Death by the Law.— There are Princes! — The King of Tunquin, and Emperor of Japan, and the Serene Cham! I would fain see a Man pretend to bite in their Courts.
Say you me so. Od! wou'd I were well there— I and a Knot of Wags that I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: And what would'st thou do before their glori∣ous Thrones?—why they'd hang thee, hang thee up, thou wretched Puppy!

Wou'd they so, old Boy! Come, I'll tell thee what, that's fair,—I'll hold thee an even Wager that I bite the Cham of Tartary, his Royal Relations, his most Honourable Privy-Council, and all his Ministers, from his Lord-Keeper to his Corn-cutter, within the Space of One Year and Six Months from the Day of the Date of these Presents.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: What, his present Majesty?
Yea verily.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: The Cham that now reigneth?
Cham or Keysar, all one to Peter, i'faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: You lie, and you're a Rascal.
Pshaw! nay! pooh! what's this for?— what, I suppose if a Man pays Scot and Lot — pray, Sir, hold, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: I'll bite you, you Dog! Bite quotha!— And are you a Biter too, Sirrah?
No, no, no, as I hope to live—I am a civil peaceable Man, and a City Sollicitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: I shall put you in mind once more of his Ma∣jesty of China. Beating him again.
'Tis very well! very well indeed! If a Man may not be a little harmlesly witty — why, Mr. Scribble∣scrabble, help! Murder! help!
How! Mr. Pinch suffering under my Uncle!— Pray, Sir, hold your Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Art thou there, Varlet! thou Enemy to East-India Companies! thou Villain thou!
Pray, Sir, be pacify'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Sirrah! I will never be pacify'd—I thought this was one of thy wicked Companions— but I'll be reveng'd of you all —I will so.—Bite the Cham of Tartary! Exit Sir Tim.
Mr. Clerimont, here has been a dreadful Ca-Ca-Catastrophe; but harkye, the Squire and your Uncle didn't know one another.

That was lucky indeed! Enough! Aside. What an unlucky Accident was this! Well, I profess I am very sorry for it. Oh he's a mad old Fellow—I wish he han't hurt your Ingenuity—I swear he has batter'd the Outside of it most abominably.
He has broke all my Head here, only for a Word speaking. Half crying. As I hope to live, I meant no more Harm! —And he has all blooded my Neckcloath here—I don't know what to do, not I.
The Squire wou'dn't be persuaded, he wou'd bite him, and so the Me-Matter happen'd.
See, here are the Ladies—come, Courage— 'twas a Misfortune your Wit brought upon you, and so the better to be endur'd.
I'de ha' giv'n a Hundred Pounds out of my Pocket, this scurvy Bus'ness had n't happen'd.
What, d'ye turn away from me? Unkind Mr. Pinch!
A little out of Order, Madam, that's all—
Oh, he has had a Misfortune.
You fright me to Death! The Matter?
Only a Rencounter, a Drubbing or so! Hark, I'll tell you. Whisper.
Dear Mr. Scribblescrabble, look in my Face— How do I look? sadly! ha!
Truly that Blow upon your Forehead has discom∣pos'd your Phisiognomy strangely.
What, ruful! dismal!
But step aside here, and we'll get some Water and a Patch, and furbish up your Countenance again as well as ever.
Will you be so kind? I shall acknowledge the Favour the longest Day I have to live.
Thus it happens, between too much Wit and too little Valour.
The poor Corpse indeed has a damn'd time on't, that's match'd with a pert Understanding, and frequent∣ly suffers for keeping bad Company.

Well, for my part, I have deduc'd it from a long Concatenation of Observations, that nothing but such extravagant Accidents attend upon the Conversa∣tions of those Impertinents they call Wits.— Mr. Friendly, I will beg one thing of you—not that I pretend to any Influence, but People in my Circum∣stances do commonly ask one thing,— my Circum∣stances! Eh! mon Coeur! what Indiscretion! My Dear, you'll pardon me?

Oh dear Madam, why this Reserve among Friends? You know Mr. Clerimont and I are of your Party.—Come out with your Request.—All your Lovers have some little fond Request or other to make before Matrimony.—
Yes, yes,—as not to chaw Tobacco, to shift in your own Dressing-Room—to have a Convenience apart, or—
O filthy! O abominable! no, no, none of these—but whatever it be, I'll engage Mr. Friendly shall make it good.
Your most obedient, humble Servant.

Well, Mr. Friendly, 'tis only this: That, for my sake, you wou'd never bite any Person, of any Sex, Age, or Condition in the World; but that, above all, you wou'd forbear your devoted and most engag'd Friend and Servant.
Forbear you, dear Madam? the most reasonable Request that was ever made in the World.
Not that I wou'd have you misunderstand me nei∣ther, dear Mr. Friendly.
If any Presumption of mine has given your La∣dyship occasion to think—
Oh fy! no, Mr. Friendly.
I do here solemnly swear and declare, in the Face of the World, that from the Day of the Date of these Presents I will most sincerely refrain, abstain and forbear—
Pish! why this is n't it, this isn't what I mean▪ this isn't what I'd be at.
From any matter or thing whatsoever that has the Honour, in any manner, to appertain or belong to your Ladyship.
Was ever any thing so insufferably ill-natur'd? to mistake a poor Woman so aukwardly, and turn her plain meaning so quite contrary to her Inclination.
But if it passes so I am mistaken.
Why I tell you, and tell you again, you take me wrong, Mr. Friendly.
Madam, I wou'd n't presume to take you at all—
Shoo! how foolish this is in you, Mr. Friendly! this Railery is very mal à propos, Mr. Friendly.—I'll vow if you persist in it, Mr. Friendly, you'll make me extreamly angry with you.
Dear Madam, what's the matter?
A foolish double entendre, my Dear.
You're discompos'd.
I'm always so with a double entendre; a double entendre always discomposes me, especially when they will mean it the wrong way, in spight of all one does to take it the right.

Nay, then there's something in it indeed— Mr. Clerimont, come, you must join with me—We'll do Mr. Friendly a good Office in spight, of his Teeth; this must come to an Ecclercissement, it may grow to a Quarrel else.
No, my Dear, there's▪ no fear of that, I, hope—Let, me smell to your Hungary-Water a little, Mr. Friendly.
Kind Creature! what a Look was there! what a Smile!
What a Grin! like a Wooden Cut of Scoggan be∣fore a Jest-Book.
Oh Brute! go to the Lady, for Shame.
Madam, you know my Forbearance was only a Mark of my Respect. Going towards her.
Ah! you Men!—well, I say no more—why would you put me in this Chafe!—you know how it is with me always — I warrant you my poor Head will suffer for it this Two Days — feel how it burns—
Was there ever such a nauseous Five and Fifty Fondling!—but how do I know but Age and Folly may make me such a Monster?
Never, 'tis impossible.
How, Clerimont, shall I never grow Old?

Certainly, if you live — but surely the Wit and Tenderness of my Mariana can never degenerate to the Folly and Fondness of such an Ideot — To be, you must be always as you are, thus dear, thus agreeable, the constant Object of my Love.
Oh, fie, fie! a marry'd Man and talk of Love! to his own Wife too!— They'll hear you, and laugh at us in their turn, if you han't a care.
But do you say you'll put me out of my Pain by to morrow Morning? 'Tis extreamly kind.
I have given you my Word, and you may depend upon it.
The Expedition of your Performance will make amends for every thing—'tis excessively kind.
Husht! not a Word more—Mariana and Cle∣rimont will find matter of Mirth out of it, and turn our Happiness into Ridicule.
See here's sweet Mr. Pinch again, as gay as if this Mishap had never befallen him, and there were no such wicked Instrument as a Cudgel in Nature.
Madam, your most humble Servant. A scurvy kind of a foolish Business happen'd to happen just now here a little odly, Madam, but no great matter, Madam, 'tis all over now.
I am very glad to see you look so well after it— I'll swear I think you're improv'd — that Patch has given a most agreeable turn to his Face — Your Opi∣nion, Gentleman.
The Patch does its Part, upon my Word— a little o'th' biggest, or so — but else wonderfully well.
And are you as found within as without, Sir?
Oh to all Intents and Purposes.
And d'ye think you could bite as well as ever?
ask my little Scribblescrabble else. — Didn't I bite your Cousin as she was dressing my Head?
None of my Cousin, Squire.
Nay, nay, she call'd you Cousin, a fat comely Gentlewoman hard by here, at the Sign of the Adam and Eve, that sells Sawsages and Black-puddings.
She's none of my Cousin, she's only my Doll's Cousin.
Why the Woman's a good Woman— What are you asham'd of your Kindred?
She's none of my Cousin. Angrily.
Ridiculous, we shall have 'em quarrel pre∣sently.
Come, come, no matter whose Cousin she is.
You bit her, you say.

Bit her! ay marry did I — and so I shou'd have serv'd all her Family, and all her Generation, if they had been here — What, han't I been at
Moscow, Isaphan, Babylon, and so forth? Knock him down!
What did he say she was my Cousin for.
To set aside this foolish Dispute, pray shew me the biting Song, which you said was set to Mu∣sick.
Here it is, and it is in the Nature of a Dia∣logue, and if your Ladyship will do me the Honour to bear a Bob with me, as I may so say, we'll perform it be∣fore all the Company.
To oblige you, Sir, I'll do my best.

SP.L: IRIS, I have long, in vain,
Been your Slave, and wore your Clog;
'Tis but just I shou'd complain,
Since you use me like a Dog.
Faithful Lovers are but few;
Cou'd I trust, I wou'd trust you:
Of all your Sex I am afraid,
And therefore vow to die a Maid.
Die a Maid! So young, so pretty!
I'll be true, by all that's good:
Die a Maid! I'll swear 'tis pitty.
Bite! Thyrsis, did you think I wou'd?
But since you will be mine alone,
Here kiss the Book and swear:
The Wedding Ring shall make us one.
Bite! Iris, now I think all's fair.
Bite! Thyrsis, now I think all's fair,
And well we may agree,
Since thus we love upon the square,
And Biters both are we.

SP.P: Rarely perform'd, upon my Word—Mr. Pinch has his Gifts — what say you, Mr. Scribblescrab∣ble?

Mighty well indeed, Sir—the Squire is a fine Gentleman, that's the truth on't—but let him be ne∣ver so well vers'd in the Arts and Sciences, he ought not to reflect upon the Family of the Scribblescrabbles.

SP.L: Oh no more of that—

SP.P: What if I did marry Mrs. Dorothy Pattypan, the Pastry-Cook's Daughter, I didn't marry all her Scoundrel Consanguinity, I hope; no, I disclaim 'em, I make her and them to know themselves, I keep 'em under, I—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Bandileer drunk, and Mrs. Scribblescrabble.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: Nay, dear Cousin Barnaby, where wou'd you haul one—I'll swear I have eat so much Goose, and drank so much Sack, that I am almost in a Quanda∣ry—Hiccup—good lack! how I have got the Hic∣cocks; well, I won't drink a drop more, profess now.
Look ye, take no care of that, I'll carry you to a Friend of mine, d'ye see, and there we'll have a Cup of rare Juniper, cure your Hiccup, I warrant you — Nothing but a cold Stomach, Cousin.
In the Name of Astonishment, what may these be, Child?
Ha! as I live, Mrs. Dorothy Scribblescrabble in her own proper Person.
What, not our little Man of Law's Consort?
The very self same, as I'm virtuous — She's half boosie too—oh ruful!
Dear Cousin, let me buss you—I love you mightily. Kisses her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: Oh gemini! — Hiccup—What makes you so rude—Hiccup—don't ye see all the Gentry here—for Shame—Hiccup—If our little Simon shou'd hear of this now—Hiccup—
Ha! how! mercy upon me! what's this I see!

STAGE.HI: Turning about, and seeing his Wife.

SP.P: Now for the Denoüement of the piece.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: Oh law!—I am ruinated and undone— there is my own Husband.
Is your Name Dorothy? ha! — Answer me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: Yes—Hiccup.
What is the reason that you set at nought my Su∣periority and Authority, and d-de-dare to come hither without my leave? Answer me quickly—Come! what say—ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: Nay, dear Simmy, don't be angry. I only came to — Hiccup — bear my Cousin Bandileer Company — I wou'dn't, for all the Varsal World, have come, Hiccup — but that you know I love Sack — Hiccup — and Walnuts mightily— Hiccup.
Cuc-cu-Cousin me no Cousins — who am I? Answer me that quickly—who am I? ha!
Look ye, I'll stand by my Cousin. She's my own Cousin, tho' I am but a private Gentleman Soldier, whereof what argues that—my Name's Barnaby Ban∣dileer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: Well, well, I know who you are well e∣nough, you are my Hony—Hiccup—but 'tis very hard if one must not — Hiccup — or go a little abroad with a — Hiccup — Relation, or so — Hiccup.
Go! you're a Quean.
Oh fie! Mr. Scribblescrabble, what! this to the Wife of your Bosom!
You're a Carrion! I'm engag'd! and Chastisement will ensue.

How? you little Brutal you— my Dear! my Dear, To Mariana. for the Honour of the Sex let us never suffer the poor Woman to be insulted before our Faces — Sure any Two of our Gender are sufficient, or of the Quorum, as they say, to keep a Husband in Order.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: Ah dear Ladies, 'tis your—Hiccup— Goodness—but 'tis an unknown thing, the Life that I—Hiccup—lead with him every Day.
Look ye if she doesn't weep, poor tender∣hearted Creature! — Come, for my sake, you must not make a Quarrel of it—What? 'twas but an inno∣cent Frolick.

SP.L: Ha! I don't love Frolicks—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: Simmy, dear Simmy, don't toss and fling, and — Hiccup — and ding up and down so — you'll break my Heart—Hiccup—
Go thou fe-fe-fe-fe-fe-false Dorothy—Elope, be gone—go to your Gallant, go—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: Oh law!—Hiccup—this is very bitter, Sobbing and Crying. I have had Seven Children, besides Four Miscarriages, and very hard Times of 'em all by him, and to be us'd thus—this is very hard.

Look ye, Gentlemen, I don't well know what to make of all this—I am amaz'd, or so, 'tis true— but she's my own Cousin—I lodge in Vinegar-Yard—
every Body knows me—I only came for the Diversion of an Interlude, or so—Do you know any thing of this matter, Sir? To Pinch.
Foolish enough, Faith! — Why really I don't know what to say to these odd kind of Circum∣stances; but pray may I crave your Name, Sir.
Sir, my Name's Barnaby.
Your Christen Name, I mean.
Oh Sir, your Servant, Sir, Bandileer, Sir.
What, is Bandileer your Christen Name?
Sir, I don't know what you mean; but I'm half Seas over—
Very merry, upon my Word, (Mr. Bandileer's woful drunk) Aside. Oh you're very sober—you've hardly wet your Lips to Day.
Say you so, Sir.
Bite!
How's that, Sir? Hey day! what, d'ye get be∣hind me?—Look ye, Gentlemen, I take you to be my Friends.
Knock him down. Standing behind Band▪ and making a very great Noise.
How, Sir! Dam ye, Sir, that won't pass nei∣ther, Sir.
Oh no harm, no harm, good Mr. Bandileer,— you must not be angry—the Gentleman means only Merriment—He's an arch Wag, if you did but know him.

Look ye, Gentlemen, if that be all, the Gentle∣man is a Stranger to me, and perhaps I may be a Stran∣ger to him; but however I'll venture a Tester or two at All-Fours with him, if he's so far forth dispos'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: Look, if you han't chaft up and down 'till you sweat like any Bull—Come, wipe your own dear sour frowzy Face with your own Doll's Handker∣chief—Hiccup—
Aa!—did I think you wou'd ha' serv'd me so!—Go— you're a hiccupping Beast—I've a good mind to send you home to the Family of the Patipans, I have so, you en-n-n-enormous Cocka∣trice.
Look ye, I brought my Cousin out—I took her up, as they say, and so, d'ye see, I'll set her down again.
These Fools begin to be troublesom, we must get rid of 'em.—Ha! here's Clever too come with Intelli∣gence from my Uncle.
I see there's Success in your Face, I dare swear the De∣sign thrives.

Admirably — the Plot is a just as that in a Critick's Play, the Parts are all ready, and we are to begin within this half Hour; but I hold it convenient to disperse this impertinent Audience first, that we may rehearse in private.
You have no farther Occasion for my biting Lo∣ver?
He may dispose of his Person how he plea∣ses—we shall hardly find him of any further Conse∣quence.
I'll pin him to Madam Scribblescrabble and her bouzy Gallant, and turn 'em adrift together.— But what shall we do with my dear Friend Stale?
Let me alone with her.—Engage Mr. Friend∣ly to trip off with the first Opportunity, and leave the rest to my Management. To Clerimont.
You won't be so unmerciful to turn her loose after him?

I must confess, running away is not the best Proof a young Fellow can give of his Courage; but
for the present Occasion tell him 'tis necessary for the Swain to fly, and the Nymph to pursue.—
Let him leave Word with his Man where we may hear of him.

Well, I vow, Mr. Pinch, you'll engage me ex∣treamly by this piece of Service, To Pinch aside. —This little impertinent Lawyer has a bus'ness of Consequence to look after for me here in Town, and this unfortunate Affair of his Wife does so exaspe∣rate his Choler, that he'll not think of it 'till we get her out of the way.
Where shall I attend your Ladyship?
Any where here in the Town.
At the Greyhound?
As proper as any, where we'll be all with you immediately, and divert our selves at the Expence of the Family of the Scribblescrabbles.
We'll laugh immoderately—Does your Lady∣ship know what Fun is?
No—but it's no matter for that.—

No, as you say, Madam, it's no matter for that; but I'll shew you such Sport, such Fun, — I'll bite Mr. Bandileer. — Look ye, Mr. Scribble∣scrabble, we'll have no more Words of this Matter, your Lady is a virtuous Person, and a good Wife, she has born you many Children, but we have all our Fai∣lings.
Ah!—name her not, dear Squire.—
Mr. Scribblescrabble, let me advise you in this Adventure— I have engag'd Mr. Pinch to serve you in it— To Scribblescrabble aside. You may trust your Wife with him, and all will be well.
Ah de-de-dear Madam, the Squire's a Gentle∣man—it wou'dn't grieve one to trust ones Wife with a Gentleman.
They're but just going hard by, we'll follow 'em presently.
Squire, dear Squire, have an Eye to Be-Be-Be-Barnaby Bandileer, my Heart misgives me plaguily.
Bite! D'ye think I don't know what to do? Trouble not your self.—Mr Bandileer's very much in Drink — but no matter for that, he'll bite so much the better.—
Hum—hum—You were a saying, Sir, To Bandileer. your Name was Barnaby.
Yes, Sir; no Offence, I hope.
Oh none at all, so much the better; I love Bar∣naby of all Names, I was born on a Barnaby-bright in the Morning. I have seen you somewhere or other, for certain.
I use the Cat and Fiddle most an End, Sir.
In Drury-Lane? Ay there it was, if I am not mightily mistaken, I have bit a Corporal that belong'd to your Company, a very merry Fellow, but I have for∣got his Name.
Kit Cunnyborrow belike.
The very same.—Look ye, you and I, and—Hark ye, Madam, To Mrs. Scribble. You and I and your Cousin here, we'll steal off, and have one healing Quart of Walnuts and Sack at the Grey∣hound.

DIV3.STAGE: Whilst Clever entertains my Lady Stale, Friend∣ly steals off.

SP.P: I must needs say you're a very civil Gentleman, Sir, and if you'll so far demeanor your self, Sir,— Look ye, Sir, if my Cousin be willing—I came with my Cousin, Sir, and I'll go with my Cousin, Sir, I'll stand and fall with my Cousin, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: I'm sure you behave your self so like a Gen∣tleman, that—hiccup—But if my Simon should take a new Vagary—oh dear—hiccup—
Oh never fear that—The Ladies have un∣dertaken to bambouzle him—they'll make him know his Duty, and beg your Pardon—now!—now take your time and steal off—take care of your Cou∣sin, Mr. Bandileer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scr.
SP.P: Oh dear, my Hiccocks is very bad.
Look ye, I'll stand and fall, that's my Word.

DIV3.STAGE: Exeunt Pinch, Band▪ and Mrs. Scribble.

SP.P: How! ha! what! Gone again! Squire, Squire!
Husht! be quiet, come hither.
Squire, dear Squire, have a care of Be-Be-Bar∣naby.
Did n't I tell you this was the only way to get rid of your Wife's Relation.
I acquiesce, Madam, I acquiesce.

Have a little Patience, Madam, and I'll set eve∣ry thing in Order. Adjusting Lady Stale's Head. I know your Ladyship uses to be the nicest Creature in the World in these Matters.—In the Name of Wonder, who cou'd it be that dress'd you to Day?
Oh I cou'd n't bear any aukward bodys Fists about me—I can't tolerate any thing but my own Wo∣man—don't you know my Woman!
Oh dear, yes, Madam, Mrs. Fiddlefaddle.
'Tis the carefullest Creature; she has liv'd with me ever since the Restoration, and never administer'd a wrong thing to me, or stuck a Pin amiss, in all the time.
The Restoration! That's a long time indeed.— You Ladyships Maid-Servants I believe are much more constant than your Men.
The Restoration did I say? the Restorati∣on? My Memory! what a thing is my Memory! I meant your other Publick Business that has happen'd here.
The Revolution?
Ay, that, that,—I take so little Notice of your Publick News!—But, as I was saying, she's the heedfullest Person in any thing that relates to my Person.
I wonder she shou'd put so little Powder in your Hair; I swear one might see it look quite gray—indeed that was a Fault in Mrs. Fiddlefaddle.
Husht! dear Clever, I wou'd n't have Friendly hear you for all the World.
Oh no danger.

Not but that mine was a meer Misfortune—The Irish Fright at that same Revolution put me into Fits, and frighted my poor Hair gray all o'the sudden.— Besides, Mariana here knows my Relations, we are all gray Ten Years sooner than other People. I come of a gray Family; don't I, my Dear? but then I wou'd n't have Mr. Friendly for many Reasons think me in Years, I know he designs having an Heir to his Family, and—
But dear Madam, why do you put your self in pain for his hearing us? I thought he had left the Com∣pany by your Order.
How left! whom, Child? What, is Mr. Friendly gone!
Gone! Did n't you see him? I'll swear I thought you had put him upon that pleasant piece of Gallan∣try.
Gallantry! oh perfidious! can it be possible! dear Clever explain your self, or I'll vow you'll put me into the Histeriques.

Nay indeed I thought it look'd a little odd for Mr. Friendly to abandon a Lady in your Ladyships Cir∣cumstances,
for a couple of the trapishest Creatures I ever saw in Masks, so miserably rigg'd, with dy'd Linings and tatter'd Furbelows.
The little nasty inconsiderable Hussys! but, dear Child, tell me, did he seem fond?

Very good! now for my share of the Lie, Aside. Excessively loving; nay, they were but too well ac∣quainted, that's certain — I heard 'em call him by his Name—Are not you a dear Dog, says one of 'em; What, my little Jenny, quo' he; and immediately whipp'd one Arm about one, and t'other about t'other, and away they scuttled together so familiarly I warrant you.
Which way are they gone?
That way, Madam; but it may be nothing but an innocent Frolick.

A Frolick, my Dear? Ah the Devil take such Frolicks, I say. You don't know what a Concern I am in; he has put me off, with a Pretence of his catching Misfortunes (as he calls 'em) by these com∣mon Sluts, these Twenty times already; and if he should catch another Misfortune we cannot be marry'd 'till he's well again, and that will be a Month, or Three Weeks at least; besides, Surgeons are so unskilful, and such Knaves, and I am so fearful of those Matters my self.—Well Dear, my Dears, forgive me.
Oh by all means, my Dear.—Ha, ha, ha! — What a terrible Fright my dear Friend was in, under the Apprehension of a Disappoint∣ment.

I must own, I have ill Nature enough to rejoice exceedingly at her Ladyships Vexation, she has been a standing Incumbrance upon poor Friendly's Pleasures for these Two Years, she has watch'd him with as much Jea∣lousie and Perversness as a barren Wife.
And has been as uneasie to him as a barren Wife's Mother, and as provoking every way— But let her be forgotten, as she ought to be, and think of your own Matters—I have just now left your Uncle.
Very much in love, I hope.
That is, just as much a Fool as you found him.

To a Tittle; he's stark mad; Love and Pe∣king, that is, your Ladyship and the Emperor of Chi∣na, have turn'd his Brains—He has made a Chi∣nese Song upon you, and I left him singing it to an Oriental Kettle-Drum, as he calls it. Next to the great Cham and Mariana, I believe I have an Interest in him.
I suppose you have been promising largely in my Name what I am never to perform.
Nay that depends upon you; a little Love, Child, that's all.
Well, he shall have all I can spare.
And I dare swear that's more than enough for his Oriental Occasions.
But I suppose you dealt with him as in the way of Trade—what Return for all this?
The Return an old Man usually makes.
Ay marry, and what's that?
To do all he can for you—and no more.
Very fair, I think.
I'll put him to it, I promise you.

I told him you had resolv'd upon parting with some of your Fortune to a poor Relation of yours, and that you requir'd him to join with you in that Set∣tlement, as a Mark of his Love, without further Enquiry, and then you wou'd be his as far as possible.
Well, and what Answer to that?
Oh he was all Rapture! consented to it, and swore immediately by half a Dozen Chinese Saints, with devilish hard Names, that he wish'd he could make your Relation Viceroy of Eastern Tartary.
Oh my Relation shall thank him; I wish he may be as fond of him when they come to be better ac∣quainted.
That I doubt of.
He expects you immediately; as we go I'll in∣struct Mr. Clerimont how to dispose of himself.—Are your Deeds ready?
Have you done as you were order'd in that matter, Mr. Scribblescrabble.
Yes, Sir, the Deeds are ready. Sighing.
The Deeds are ready!—What doleful Voice is that? Can that be Mr. Scribblescrabble! Is it pos∣sible, the gay, the witty, the gallant Mr. Scribblescrab∣ble?
Ah good lack! my De-De-Doll's false—perhaps you don't know that.
False! is that all? A Trifle—be false again, be as false to her as she can be to you for the Life of her—Give her as good as she brings.
Nay, I told him 'twas below the Character of a fine Gentleman, and a Man of the Town, as he is, to discompose his Noble Soul for any thing a Wife can do or say.
No, no, he has forgot it, or will do it in a very little while longer.—Indifference is the Word, and Madam Scribblescrabble may dispose of her Person as she thinks fit.
Nay, I had n't so much car'd for it, had'nt it been for that Son of a Whore, that Be-Be-Barnaby Bandileer.

Care for it! — Nay, if you once come to care for your Wife, farewel Gallantry,—why, you'll be Company for no Body but Haberdashers,
Tinmen, Trunk-makers, and such comical kind of Peo∣ple.
Nay, I always had a Spirit above these pe-pe-paultry Matters too—I de-de-dont know how I came to marry the Jade, unless it were for Form sake, or out of Cu-Cu-Custom, as they say.

No!—And tho' you fancy you are vex'd at her now, I fancy 'tis only for Form's sake, and out of Custom, as you say—Come, come along with us, and think of the Hundred Guineas you're to get of Mr. Friendly, — why 'twill buy you Claret and Mirth enough to make you actually believe you are a Widower.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: SIlly Swain, give o're thy wooing,
Sighing, gazing, kissing, cooing,
All is very foolish doing.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: All that follows after Kisses,
The very best, the Bliss of Blisses,
Is as dull a Joy as this is.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: Prove the Nymph, and taste her Treasure,
Tell me then, when full of Pleasure,
What dull thing thou can'st discover,
Duller than a happy Lover.
Silly, silly Swain give over, &c.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Angelica, Mariana, and Mrs. Clever.

SP.P: WELL, Madam, don't you think my Father now one of the strangest Old Gentlemen that ever you saw with your Eyes? Oh gemmini! I wou'd n't marry such a strange sort of an Old Fellow for all the World.
No, nor she neither, Child, notwithstanding all the violent Protestations of good Will she made him but now.
I'll swear I think there is something very agreea∣ble and entertaining in Sir Timothy's Humour.
Nay, indeed all the ill that you can say of him is, that he's an Old Man, and for my part I think all Old Men are alike.
Oh dear, in what, Madam?
In being good for nothing, Madam.
Oh dear! I don't think so, I fancy I could like some sort of Old Men strangely, they're so civil and com∣plaisant, and so neat, and so clean, and shav'd so close, I warrant ye.
Should you like Mr. Friendly if he were Old, Madam?

As for Mr. Friendly indeed, Madam, he's a kind of a perfect Stranger to me, so that I don't know what Judgment to make of his Temper or Inclinations; he
may be a very good sort of a Man for ought I know, not but that I can't help thinking Mr. Friendly has some Humours may make a Woman very uneasie when she is—

Not so absolute a Stranger to him as you are▪ [Smiling.] Are not you a little Hypocrite? Hark ye; Hitting her with her Fan. Do you intend to be marry'd to Night to a Man that you are such an absolute Stranger to?
Oh la! I wonder what makes you talk so— who could put such a thing into your Head?
He that put it into yours, Friendly.
I'll swear he gives himself a strange Liberty of talking.
None but what you'll forgive him for, I dear swear.
He fancy'd, if he did n't tell, you wou'd.
Well, I wonder at his Confidence.
For being before-hand with you. Really Love Matters are come to be manag'd after a very fantastical manner, and all the Care is now, not who shall keep the Secret best, but who shall tell first.
I'll vow I have a good Mind not to have him, he's such a meer blab.
That would be all wrong, as they say, Madam, to fall out with him, and be reveng'd upon your self.
She'll consider better of it, never fear.

Well, but dear Madam, we are of your Party, and I hope you take us to be so much your Friends as to deserve your Confidence—You know we have no other Design upon Sir Timothy, but in order to bring this Business, between Mr. Friendly and you, to a happy Conclusion.

Nay, really I must needs say I have been infi∣nitely oblig'd to you, dear Madam — And indeed my Father is such a strange kind of a Man, that I don't
care what risque I run to get out of his Clutches. Well, but you know Mr. Friendly, Madam. To Mariana.
A little, Madam, not so well as you do, I fancy.

Oh dear, yes to be sure you do, and a great deal better too; but do you think he'll make a good Hus∣band? I believe he's a strange wild young Fellow, really a Woman runs a strange hazard with these wild young Fellows.

All Gamesters that play deep, and push for a Fortune, run Hazards, and for my part I am always for risquing with a wild Fellow rather than a tame one— besides, were he never so wild, Matrimony will make him bate of his speed, as they say that have try'd it.
I'll vow I have heard he drinks a World of Claret.

SP.L: And you fancy that will make him so slee∣py—

SP.P: If I don't wonder what you can mean by that — Well, Mrs. Clever, you are the maliciousest Creature, you are always a teizing one, but I'm resolv'd I'll be reveng'd of you at Night when we are a-bed to∣gether.
A-bed together! for Shame! why you wou'd n't abandon your Bridegroom for me?

Nay, Mrs. Clever, you know when you lye here you always use to be my Bed-fellow, and you shan't be put out of your Bed for any Body, I'm resolv'd you shall lye with me, and we'll lye awake and talk all Night long—Nay, I'm resolv'd I'll pinch you if you won't lye awake and talk to me.
No, no, you know I'm the sleepiest Crea∣ture in the World: — You had better pinch Friendly if he won't lye awake and — talk to you.
I'll swear I have a good Mind to stop your Mouth—I think the Woman's md to talk so— Oh gemini!
Methinks Sir Timothy stays very long—did n't he promise to folow us immediately.
He's a teaching the Servants to Dance, as they do before the Emperor of China.
I wish he wou'd dispatch the Business we want to have done, and go on with his Tartarian Ballet af∣terwards.
Shall I go and tell him you want to speak with him, Madam?
If you please, Madam.

He'll leave the Cham of Tartary himself to wait upon you. Going. Dear Mrs. Clever, if you shou'd happen to see Mr. Friend∣ly, I charge you don't tell him we Coming back. have been talking of him— We shall have him so vain, and in his Airs, I warrant you.
No, no, you shall have the Pleasure of betraying the Secret, and telling him all your self — but pray make haste and dispatch your Embassie.
I'll be here again in a Minute.
Well, what think you of Mrs. Friendly that is to be?
She's in a most violent twitter.
As all young Ladies of her Age are at the ap∣proach of Matrimony.
She's so out of breath, and so merry, and so grave, and so glad, and so smirking, and so smiling.
And doesn't know whether she goes upon her Head or her Heels.
Love! Love! my Dear! you know this Love is the Devil—Ha! pray look this way, Looking out. is not that the most serene, and most amiable Mr. Pinch that's coming into the Court?
'Tis he, there are certain foolish Appurtenances belonging to his Face and Person, which no one else can pretend to — but I think we are ready for him, and so let him come as soon as he pleases.
I wou'd n't have him see me.
No, we'll go look upon your Oriental Lover's Preparations for your Entertainment. Exeunt.
If it shall seem agreeable to you to repose your most worshipful Person in this Place, I will notifie your Arrival to Sir Timothy Tallapoy, Knight and Mandarin of the Seventh Order.

'Tis very well, Friend, notifie to your Master with what haste you can conveniently, but don't discom∣pose your self, don't put your self out of Order. Exit Servant. Very foolish, Faith! If the rest of my Father-in-law's Family be of a piece with this Fellow, I shall have a good merry time on't among 'em—to be the only Wit in the Family —I don't know, it may be well enough— 'tis better biting than being bit, certainly — Who'd have thought that sly Devil, that Mrs. Mariana, shou'd have had it in her to put such a practical Bite upon one—It cost me Two Hours in Time, besides Eight and a Penny in Monies number'd to stay for her, and she never to come at last.—Very pretty Manners truly— I smoak somewhat between that same Clerimont and her, but no matter, Bite's the Word. I shall be even with her before to morrow Morning—I believe, if I play'd one, I play'd Forty Games at All-Fours and Shovel-Board with Mr. Bandileer — Poor Fellow, he was bloodily in for it at last—'Tis true, indeed he drank a World of Geneva — but his Cousin will take Care of him—She's a discreet Woman truly in the main, I
believe—she held his Head so kindly when he grew a little sickish—Ha! ha! 'tis he!
The Lord Chancellor of Moscow's mad Mace-bearer!— How the Devil shou'd he get hither! —I wou'd I were well got by him—I wonder they suffer him to walk about with such a Stick in his Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: I'll consummate this Affair with my Son-in-law Pinch as soon as may be, and I will then— Ha! how! here is that wretched Puppy that goeth up and down seeking whom he may bite—Is there no Place safe against biting, not even a Man's own House? — You take a strange Liberty, Friend, after some Occurrences that pass'd between us so lately.

A strange Fellow this, I don't know what to do, not I—I must try to speak him fair, I think, and see if one can mollifie him that way, for 'tis but a Word and a Blow with him, that I see clearly. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Now is this wicked Villain meditating a Bite, but by the Majesty of Peking, I will confound the Evil Imagination e'er it can be brought to Perfection— Heark to me, young Man, you are one of those that make themselves merry with the most excellent Oriental Nations: This Mansion was not built to receive those Peo∣ple that scoff at the Cham of Tartary.
Oh dear Sir, far be it from me, Sir, to think it was, Sir; I can't think it was built with any such knavish Design—I am strangely tempted to bite him. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: I am therefore prompted to ask what Affair, or Negotiation might induce you to enter here.
This is most execrably impertinent. Aside. Affair, Sir? why really I have an Affair, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Ay! discuss to me of what Nature.
Nature, Sir? If I cou'd come to the Speech of the proper Person—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Sir, I notifie to you that I am the most pro∣per Person of any one within these Walls to whom you may unfold your Bus'ness.
Look ye, Sir, that isn't the Matter—I don't say but you may be very proper for ought I know, but my Bus'ness at present lyes more properly with the Gen∣tleman of the House.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Then I notifie to you again that it lyes with me—come, bar Biting, and begin.
Good lack! it's much the Loss of a Place shou'd do this. Aside. Pray, Sir; no Harm, I hope; by your Leave only.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Whither wou'd you pass, Friend?
Only that way a little—just in at that Door, that's all—I shall meet with some of the Family, I won't trouble you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Sir, I have undertaken the discussing your Business my self, and 'till I have made some further Pro∣gress in it the Family shall not be met with, — No, Sir, by the most Potent and Serene Cham they shall not.
Pray, Sir, let me tell you, this is very unci∣vil, Sir,—I don't know but I may be in haste, and so forth, and may have an Occasion to speak with a dear Friend that lyes dangerously sick in the House.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: The Mansion is salubrious and healthy; but if it were not, may I suppose you to be a Maker up or Preparer of Medicines, or, as the Western Language ren∣ders it, an Apothecary.
Bite! Od I've a good Mind,—'twas at my Tongue's end. Softly aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Ha! What is it thou pronouncest in se∣cret?
