Nothing, nothing in the Universe, but only that I beg the Favour of a Word or two with Sir Ti∣mothy Tallapoy:—That's all, as I hope to breath, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Prodigious! How enormously he varies his Fable!—Say on, I am he, —tho' thou knew'st it before, thou biting Viper thou! I am he—pronounce, say on.
Oh dear! this is worse and worse!—You he! alas! I wou'd you were but—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Speak, what?
Your self, Sir, that's all, only a friendly Wish, I wou'd you were your own Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Soho! My faithful Servants, approach;— I'll teach you to bite one of the worshipful Oriental Tra∣ders in his own Mansion.— Would'st thou infer that I am distracted, of a Mind not sit to negotiate? Sirrah! I have been thought fit to negotiate and drink Tea with the most excellent Governor of Canton, nay with the Viceroy, and the learned Lipous.

Look ye, Friend, I don't say any Body's mad, but these are odd Circumstances, and Moorfields is a good Air for People that lose Places—when one comes about Bus'ness, to be interrupted, and interrogated, and bam∣bouzled, and not suffer'd to —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: So ho! my Servants!
Pshaw! This is a Jest indeed! hey day! what's the meaning of all this? Look ye, my Name's Squire Pinch, I come to marry Sir Timothy Tallapoy's Daugh∣ter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Dost thou bite me with the Name of mine Allie!—Seise on him, the Wretch!

This is damn'd foolish, faith and troth!— Look ye, I am Sir Peter Pinch's Son and Heir,—I am a Man of Wit and Pleasure, I understand the Town, and I won't be us'd so for ne'er a Mace-bearer nor a Mad∣man in Moscow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Incontinently I think thou art distracted thy self, but it suffices me that I know thee to be a Biter, the Name that comprehends all kind of Villany — Cou'd the right worshipful and most sincere, my Friend, Sir Peter Pinch, a Man of his most categorical Princi∣ples, engender a Biter! impossible! out, thou Impo∣stor!
So ho! what's there no body here to take one's part! Sir Timothy Tallapoy!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Hold him fast.
The Lovers will be past reprieving presently— I left 'em mumbling over Matrimony with as much Eagerness, as if they were to be happy in good ear∣nest.
Very well, now for our Cue here—Matters have happen'd as we cou'd have wish'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Most exceeding fair, and my very good Friend, my propitious Stars have directed me to the Discovery of a notorious Imposture, and your excel∣lent Persons come very opportunely to behold my Ju∣stice.
Well, Friend, if he be never so much your Ma∣ster, and the individual numerical Sir Timothy, I am as much the individual numerical Squire Pinch as he is the individual numerical Sir Timothy Tallapoy.

I must confess he has a strange designing kind
of a Face,—I shou'd be very cautious of trust∣ing such a sort of a Man upon his bare Word.
Dear Sir Timothy have a Care of him, methinks I see Biting written in his very Forchad.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Madam, the sage Orientals are not easily bit.
Oh Ladies, your humble Servant—very foo∣lish, faith and troth!—Now you shall see Friend— these Ladies know me. — Madam, here's really a very foolish Adventure.

What does he mean? he addresses his Discourse to us.— Bless me, I'm afraid he's distracted— how he looks! For Goodness sake don't come too near him.—They say 'tis as bad as Poison to be bit by a Madman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: It is, Madam, what we may properly call an egregious degree of Folly mixt with an egregious degree of Impudence—'tis what the Learned in the Western Nations call a Complication.
Pshaw! phoo! this is all fooling! Ladies! Ma∣dam! here are a whimsical Set of People wou'd persuade me my Name is n't Pinch.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: I told your Ladyship what he drives at, he wou'd bite me under a wrong Name.
And pray, Sir,—oh dear—hold him fast,— is your Name Pinch?
Bite! Bite! Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: You see, most excellent Lady, you see what he wou'd be at.
And do you really think, Sir, your Name is Pinch?
Nay, Madam, I tell you I'm like to be us'd scur∣vily—this is all ridiculous! Speak Truth now—why as if you didn't know one! — This is Biting in∣deed!
Bless me! my Dear! did you ever see this Man before?
Never with my Eyes, Madam.—Sir Timothy, let me conjure you to have a care, there is certainly some very villainous Design laid against you, this is some Plot.
What is the Meaning of all this?—Did n't I come down in the Coach with you to Day? Mrs. Maria∣na! Madam!

The confident Wretch! He has got your Name too!—Hark ye, Friend, what Good does it do you now to counterfeit another Body's Name? Why you cou'd n't think but it must needs be found out at last, and then you know the Law is very severe in these Cases.
'Tis very probable he had his Eye upon the young Lady's Fortune.
Why this is downright making a Fool of one: I thought you had been more a Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Bohee! Do you To a Servant. and your Fellows take care to confine him in the Cel∣lar—I will supplicate the Mandarins of Justice that Punishment may be inflicted according to his Demerits— Away with him.
I never saw the like in my Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Madam, we live in a flagitious biting Age, and a biting Climate—Away with him—For my part, I wish I were well turn'd of the Cape of Good-hope.

Prithee be quiet, Friend — Talk of putting one in a Cellar! Phoo! what a Jest is that? Nay I won't stir a Foot, that's flat—Help! Murder! Ladies? Why you won't? What, will you pull ones Arm off? You'll answer all this—If ever I bite any Body again—pray—stay—hear me—
Upon my Word I am heartily frighten'd; he makes a most terrible Noise—I believe the best way will be to get him out of the House.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Fear nothing, Lady, I will so muzzle him.
That he can neither bite nor bellow, 'tis the best Course you can take with him.
Well, of all the disagreeable things one meets with, nothing is so shocking to me as a Biter—You meet with nothing of this kind in China, Sir Timothy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: 'Twou'd be Felony, without Benefit of Clergy.
Well, they are a polite People!—how agreea∣bly graceful is that Habit of Sir Timothy's, what an I∣mage of the Eastern Wisdom it gives us!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: They are certainly a great People; Arts be∣gan with them—It is thought the necessary Sciences of Eating and Drinking were discover'd some Ages among them before they were known in Europe.
Concerning Beards and their Management I have heard indeed—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: The whole Oeconomy of the Beard was treat∣ed of Seven Thousand Years ago, by a learned Chinese Philosopher, in Fifteen Volumes.—Ah, Madam, might I but hope for the Pleasure of seeing your Ladyship in the most glorious City of Peking, I wou'd n't come hi∣ther again to be Emperor of the West.
We Women are born to obey—Sir Timothy may be sure I shall follow my Husband all the World over.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Happy! happy Man will he be.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Angelica, Friendly disguis'd, Scribblescrabble with Writings.

SP.P: Here's a Gentleman enquires for your Ladyship.
Sir Timothy, this is my Relation, in whose Be∣half we are to do the charitable Deed I spoke to you of.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Sir, you are honour'd!—Your Character is Affinity with the Illustrious.
Sir, I have always conceiv'd as much.

Oh gemini! the Thing is done, To Clever aside. and I vow I'm glad 'tis over. I wou'd n't have it to do again for all the World—Mr. Friendly did look so up∣on one, and my Heart did go so pit-a-pat all the while.
Husht! be quiet now. You shall talk to me of it for Two Hours together by and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Are the Deeds drawn according to your La∣dyships Command and Direction?
Exactly, if you do us the Honour to concur, the Matter is at an End.
You deliver this as your Act and Deed, Sir, for the Use of this Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: I do, Sir, with my full Intentions, Mariana and Sir Tim. execute the Deed. and wish much Happiness may hereby redound and accrue to him.
Sir, I must always acknowledge you the Author of my Happiness, and will take an Opportunity to con∣vince you of my Gratitude.
Tell not me, Mr. Clerimont, I'm not to be fobb'd off so—I'll find him out if he be above Ground.
Why, I tell you he's just now upon making his Fortune, and you'll ruin all.
I tell you I'll have him whole and sole, as the Law directs, with all his Ways, Water-courses, Easments, and Appurtenances, I'll not bate him an Inch.
Look ye, Sir, the Matter is gone To Friendly. as far as 'twill bear, and you have nothing to do now but to make good the Ground we have got for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: What is the Meaning of this? What does this Lady's Passion import?
Some Weeping and much Talking, I believe. Ten to One but she tells us more of her Mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Madam, may I enquire— To Lady Stale.
Sir, I am reduc'd to the last Extremity, I am de∣feated and evil entreated, I am desesperè, by the most in∣constant Person—
That ever had the Honour to be in fair Lady's Favour. Pulling off his Disguise.

Oh are you there, Sir? 'Tis exceeding well in∣deed! I am given to understand that you are faithless, Sir, that you are false, Sir, that you are making your Bo∣dy over, by a Marriage-Contract, to the Daughter of Sir Timothy Tallapoy, in order to defraud me, your lawful Creditor, of my natural Dues and Perquisites.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: How, most exceeding fair Lady, are there Machinations against your most faithful humble Servant? Is your Relation Mr. Friendly? To Mariana.
Since the Matter is out, 'tis most certainly so, my Relation is Mr. Friendly, or Mr. Friendly is my Rela∣tion, you may take it either way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: But Madam!—
But Sir Timothy! I hope you won't quarrel with him for that: Hark ye, let me talk with you a little.
And does common Fame really say all this?
Ay marry does it, to thy Shame, thou Traitor!

Look ye, for the matter of the Matrimony 'tis too true; but for the other part, I stand up for my Con∣stancy, and do aver I was never false in my Life; for my Trial I put my self upon my Country here present, and your Ladyship may go on with the Evidence as soon as you see fit.
Oh Wretch! do'st thou not expect the House shou'd fall down upon thee this Instant?
No, I trust in the Timber-work.
Oh thou Wickedness incarnate! How often hast thou look'd upon me and smil'd, and then smil'd and look'd upon me again?
Very often truly, being for the most part of a merry Disposition, as the worshipful Bench here know.
But say how often amorously, say, speak truth, if thou dar'st.
Never.
A short Answer that.
Madam, I believe he has squeez'd this poor Hand— Crying.
Did you squeeze that filthy bony thing? You shan't touch mine.
'Till I have been forc'd to cry, oh!
Very barbarous that, in my Mind.
But no sign of Love.
Oh none at all.
Did n't you promise me to put me out of my Pain before to morrow; out of my Pain, I stick to that.
And Faith, I think I have been as good as my Word, the Devil's in't if you don't know what to trust to now.

Ah! thou art a Fellow of sweet Principles! but I know what you want, you want to put me in a Fit, do you, but I'll do my best to keep it down. Sobbing. Oh! how it heaves! how it heaves here. Dear Clever, ease my Lace quickly, or I shall drop down, I am not able to bear it.

Nay, Madam, he's a most perfidious Wretch, that's certain; but since you see there is no good to be done with him, you had much better retire before you fall into a fresh Disorder; you'll only give him an occasi∣on of a malicious Grin.
Mr. Clerimont tells you true; these Rattle-headed young Fellows don't know how to value a discreet elder∣ly Passion.

Ah, Clever, thou art certainly in the right, I'll leave him to his Flirt! Well, this is my Fifteenth Mis∣fortune of this kind since I have been a Widow— But I'll retire into the Country this Instant I'm resolv'd, and mind good Books, and making Sweetmeats and Salves, and never trust in a Man of Five and Twenty a∣gain.
And will she go? Will the dear Creature go?
Well, I'll swear you're a cross-grain'd ill-natur'd thing, I'll vow I've a good Mind to hate you.
What, for sacrificing all to you, you dear little Creature!
Be quiet can't you! Don't you see my Father?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Well, Madam, you see your Power over your Slave—Mr. Friendly, as this Lady has done you the Honour to interceed for you, I declare I receive you as my Son-in-law, and will make good what I seal'd to for my Daughter's Fortune—I hope you are no Biter.
A most profess'd Enemy to all Fools of that kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: I like you the better, you may come to good.
The Peasant Gregory Grumble, who was impri∣son'd in the Cellar, notifies to your Worthiness, that the Person last committed is the very real Esquire Pinch, his Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Ha! say'st thou! the Circumstance displea∣seth— Let him be releas'd, I am glad my Daughter is not bitten however—It must be of great Grief to his Parents, to hear that he taketh unto Biting after this manner.

Look ye, Gentlemen and Ladies, this is mighty fine, very exceeding fine; here have Gregory and I been put in a Cellar among old Shoes, broken Bottles, and wicker Baskets, for no manner of substantial reason in the Earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Young Gentleman, the Disaster has been of your own seeking. I am sorry to say it, but tho' you were Ten times the Son of my Friend Sir Peter Pinch, and a Biter, I wou'd not affie my Daughter to you.
Ya!—you may take your Daughter and stop your—I wou'd n't marry her an' she were a Cherubin.
For ought I see 'tis well the matter has happen'd as it has, since the only one thing that ever Sir Timothy and Mr. Pinch cou'd have agreed in, wou'd have been in not liking one another.
Well perhaps 'twas, and perhaps 'twan't, Madam. Look ye, I desire you not to concern your self about me, I shan't concern my self about you, poz.
Why this is all right again, for we are certainly agreed as to that matter too, however I promise to wear a Willow for your sake when I hear you are sped.
Well, well, you may wear what you please, I believe I know what your Husband will wear, sweet Madam Nimble-Chops.
Don't be in a Choler, and I'll bring you ac∣quainted with my Husband. Sir Timothy, it is some time since that I have had a very particular Esteem for your Family.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Madam, you confer Honour.
And in order to make my self a Part of it, about a Week ago I was marry'd to this Gentleman, your Ne∣phew. Pointing to Clerimont.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: How, to my Nephew! oh thou most perfi∣dious! Is it possible?
The thing is most certainly so, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Is it so, Sir? Why then the World is all false, there is nothing but Villany, Biting—Jilting—
Bite! What, art thou bit at last, Old Boy, Old Fobus, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Get thee out of my Doors this Minute, thou most egregious wretched Puppy, or I will so batter that Scull of thine—
Hold, keep the Peace—take away his Stick— what d'ye mean, ha! what wou'd you be at? d'ye think Heads are made for nothing but to be broke? Very pretty Sport, truly.
Come, Sir Timothy, be pacify'd, I fancy we shall agree much better as Uncle and Neice, than as Man and Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tim.
SP.P: Oh thou false Creature! I am enrag'd, and wish all the Western World was on Fire—But I'll take Post for the East-Indies this Instant, and never con∣verse with Man, Woman or Child again, that was born on this side the Cape of Good-hope. Exit Sir Tim.
Let him go, we shall find some way to mollifie him, I warrant you, when the first Heat is over.

Q.L: Short are the passionate Fits of Love and Rage,
Which warm the sickly Veins of feeble Age.
Blaze out, and for a Moment seem to rise,
Yet soon the Fuel fails, and then it dies.
